Transcript: It's early morning.
Two men emerge from a Christmas mist.
Me, Ezra Koenig, and poet/painter Jake Longstreth.
We meet with hot chocolates in our hands and enter the Time Crisis studio, and we're going
to take phone calls from Rashida Jones, Alana Haim, and some fans.
This is Time Crisis Christmas.
Time Crisis with Ezra Koenig.
That was the kinks with Father Christmas.
Thanks for coming over so early, Jake.
Yeah, man. Tired.
There are probably some people still up, listening.
Yeah. I hope so.
We're dedicated, so we're here.
That's right.
That song was pretty good.
Yeah, that's a good one.
That was kind of the kinks getting a little punky.
Mm-hmm.
Late '70s kinks.
That's one of the few Christmas rock songs that has its own integrity.
It's not just pure novelty.
I could listen to that song, or I could hear that song any time of the year
and be like, "Yeah, that's a good song."
Right. I know what you mean.
Not all Christmas songs have integrity.
You know what happens to me when people just make these trash Christmas songs
just to get something out?
Right.
Or for just some random compilation or something?
You know what, to me, is the most integrity-possessing move?
Is when a Christmas song is just on your regular album.
That is strong.
You know what I mean?
Because it's not like Michael Buble, "Okay, here's your Christmas album
that you're going to have at $6.99 at Target as a classic stocking stuffer."
It really shows that you have a love of Christmas, a love of Christianity,
when you actually put a Christmas song, just like track 7 on your album.
The Everly Brothers, 1971 album, "Stories We Tell Ourselves."
There's a song called "Christmas Eve Can Kill You."
Whoa.
Beautiful song.
And that was not a Christmas album.
Nope, straight-up album.
Let's do it.
Here's a Christmas song with some real integrity from the Everly Brothers,
"Christmas Eve Can Kill You."
